# VISUAL CONTENT EXTRACTION

## Header/Branding
- **Logo/Brand**: "BLESSED TRADER."
- **Tagline**: "Your guide to consistency in the industry of trade."
- **Visual Element**: Moon phases illustration (crescent, full moon, phases sequence)

## Main Content

### Primary Heading
**LIQUIDITY**

---

## Page Structure
- Minimalist layout
- Black header section with white text
- White/light background for main content area

- Significant white space below heading

---

## Notes
- This appears to be a title/section page
- No body text, charts, tables, or additional content visible
- Clean, professional design aesthetic
- No checklists, bullet points, or structured data present on this view

What you need to know about Liquidity?
Liquidity: In technical terms Liquidity refers to the degree which market can be quickly 
bought or sold without affecting the asset’s price.
Liquidity will be above old lows & highs, that’s where the “Smart Money” will be targeting –
knocking out the liquidity that was resting below these old lows, then seek liquidity above 
old highs.

Simple example of price running the Buy-Side Liquidity 
before heading lower.
Price expanded to the higher to take out buy stops, why? Because they (the 
Informed Money), will want to sell at a higher price, take the Liquidity and cover 
their long positions that they opened to run the price higher.
So, they aim at the Liquidity Pool (in this example BSLQ), they open long 
positions to push the price higher into the BS Liquidity Pool, then use that 
Liquidity to cover Long positions, and open Short positions at a higher price.

High resistance Liquidity
When we see market making higher highs & higher lows after already running the sell-
side liquidity, we can’t reasonably expect for price to drop all the way down below the 
main low to take those stops out. There will be a lot of resistance like:
Bullish orderblocks (unless all of them are already very clearly mitigated and it’s a 
“Trendline Phantom in the making), then doesn’t matter how much liquidity there is 
below these main lows.
It’s a “high resistance liquidity run”, so in other words, the more time price spent around 
that area actually making clear, one-sided moves, running sell-side liquidity, etc., the 
more unlikely that price will drop to the main old low despite the level of liquidity resting 
there.

Low resistance Liquidity
What retail sees as a “double bottom” area as strong support, what we see is all 
the sell stops resting below (retail stop losses) – that’s our target and a magnet 
where the price will be drawn to.
All the double, triple tops & bottoms, consolidations that are slowly going lower 
or higher – that’s our target, that’s what we want to see. We’re not going to trade 
away from these types of lows/highs, we’re going to trade directly into it.
Low resistance liquidity run is when aggressive acceleration happens leaving 
liquidity void – that’s when everything that builds up to fill it is considered as low 
resistance until price reaches the opposing array’s, so if a big drop happened, and 
price starts building longs to fill it – it’s a low resistance run until price reaches 
first bearish array like a bearish breaker, orderblock, and so on.

Run on Liquidity before retracing
When we know what the Higher TF orderflow is we wait for retracements 
to ride the direction towards the Higher TF draw on Liquidity. It‘s 
important to pay attention not only where the price pulls back but also 
what it does before pulling back, so there‘re two scenarios:
1.
Price will run Liquidity, give a break of structure and then pull back
2.
Or after a strong expansion price will not run any Liquidity, and just 
slowly start to form (in this case) higher highs, higher lows
So, when price runs Liquidity before retracing – usually it will pull back 
deeper + the retracement will take longer AND when price does not run 
Liquidity before retracing, that‘s when it‘s more likely that the pull back 
won‘t last long, price will reach the first strong opposing level, and 
attack the Higher TF target + the low that price left before pulling back.

# BLESSED TRADER
**Your guide to consistency in the industry of loss.**

---

## LEFT DIAGRAM - CONCEPTUAL RANGE STRUCTURE

### HIGH RESISTANCE
**WHEN PRICE HEADS INTO THE PREMIUM AREA WHERE THERE'RE ALL THE BEARISH LEVELS (BARRIERS (PREMIUM POAS))**

*Bearish Premium Array (breaker, orderblock, etc.)*

### LOW RESISTANCE RUN
**UNTIL PRICE GOES INTO THE PREMIUM SIDE OF THE RANGE AND REACHES PREMIUM BEARISH LEVELS.**

[Simple line chart showing price movement oscillating between high and low resistance zones, with an upward trend in the low resistance zone]

---

## MIDDLE DIAGRAM - CANDLESTICK CHART EXAMPLE

### HIGH RESISTANCE
*-breaker-*
*-breaker-*

### LOW RESISTANCE
**TILL FIRST BEARISH ARRAY IS REACHED**

[Candlestick chart showing price action with bullish movement from low resistance zone breaking into high resistance zone, with two breaker levels marked]

---

## RIGHT DIAGRAM - INVERSE SCENARIO

### LOW RESISTANCE
**TILL FIRST BULLISH ARRAY IS REACHED**

*+DE*

### HIGH RESISTANCE

[Candlestick chart showing price action with initial upward movement followed by downward trend, demonstrating the inverse of the middle scenario - price moving from high resistance down through low resistance zone]

BAIT AND SLAM
Whenever you see price not showing any directional one-sided moves, when the 
momentum is low and price is either forming double, triple bottoms or price 
forms a low then a small higher high & higher low close to it, then another one –
it’s like the markets are laying cheese below it – that’s what we target, that’s 
what we focus on while retail traders try to trade away from it!
It’s a smart idea to build a totally separate folder just for Liquidity.
Do your analysis, explain to yourself what you think happened there save & 
collect screenshots like that, it will help you to understand where the price is 
drawn to, which areas act like “magnet”.

# BLESSED TRADER.
*Your guide to consistency in the industry of loss.*

---

## LEFT CHART - PROTECTED LOW

**RUN ON STOPS**

**BREAK OF STRUCTURE** [shown with dashed horizontal line]

**PROTECTED LOW**
Price ran the SSLQ, then expanded higher broke the structure respecting bullish levels (bullish orderflow).

[Chart shows zigzag price pattern with downward trend line, breaking above structure line, with a boxed low area and upward arrow indicating bullish continuation]

---

## MIDDLE CHART

**Low of PDA (Continuous Block, FVG, etc.)**
**BLOCK OVERLAPPING**

[Chart shows price pattern with gray horizontal zones/blocks, arrows pointing upward and downward showing price interaction with these zones]

## RIGHT CHART - UNPROTECTED LOW

**Sell-side liquidity (SSLQ)**

**UNPROTECTED LOW**
Price been forming small Higher lows, equal lows do strong & directional moves, the liquidity is building below it (small lows).

[Chart shows zigzag price pattern with horizontal gray zone at top, boxed area highlighting equal lows, followed by strong downward move indicated by arrow, demonstrating failure to protect the low]

# LIQUIDITY ABOVE/BELOW CONSOLIDATION

## Header Text:
**BLESSED TRADER.**
"Your guide to consistency in the industry of trade."

## Main Title:
**LIQUIDITY ABOVE/BELOW CONSOLIDATION**

## Explanatory Text:
WHEN THE PRICE IS GOING SIDEWAYS (CONSOLIDATING) THE LIQUIDITY (RETAIL STOPS) ARE BUILDING ABOVE & BELOW IT, AND IN MOST CASES PRICE WILL WANT TO SWEEP BOTH SIDES BEFORE PICKING A DIRECTION.

## Left Diagram - Schematic Representation:
- Simple line chart showing price movement
- **BUY-SIDE LIQUIDITY** - labeled at upper consolidation area with red shaded box above
- **SELL-SIDE LIQUIDITY** - labeled at lower consolidation area with red shaded box below
- Shows price sweeping both liquidity zones before directional move upward

## Right Diagram - Actual Chart Example:
- Candlestick chart showing real price action
- **BUY-SIDE LIQUIDITY** - labeled at upper horizontal consolidation zone
- **SELL-SIDE LIQUIDITY** - labeled at lower horizontal consolidation zone
- Red shaded boxes marking liquidity sweep zones:
  - Upper right: above consolidation high
  - Lower right: below consolidation low
- Chart demonstrates price sweeping both sides of consolidation range before making directional moves

What to do when you have Liquidity on both sides, how to 
know which side the market is going to choose?
When that’s the case, we focus on the underlying higher time-frame bias. Very 
important rule to remember is that higher time-frames are like a “parent” figure 
to the lower ones, meaning that if the 1H orderflow is bullish but there’s a 5min 
consolidation that is building buy-side liquidity above and sell-side liquidity below 
there’s a big chance that both sides will get swept, however, the overall direction 
will stay bullish.
To sum up, if we have a clear Daily target that is higher, the 1H orderflow is 
bullish, and 5min time-frame is stuck in a range (example on the right) – price 
will sweep both sides but keep on going higher until the Daily target is reached 
and or 1H bullish orderflow & structure is broken.

Where do we look for liquidity despite, clean lows, equal 
lows, consolidations, etc.?
- Highs & Lows of Asia Session: 08:00 PM to 00:00 AM NY time
- Highs & Lows of London Session: 02:00 AM to 05:00 AM NY time
- Highs & Lows of NY Session: 07:00 AM to 10:00 AM NY time
- Intra-day Highs & Lows before Equity Opening: 09:30 AM NY time

Price needs to sweep Liquidity before every strong move 
that’s directional & momentum driven.
Before every one-sided, strong move the “Informed Money” will grab the liquidity 
that’s resting above the highs or below the lows (where retail traders place their 
stop losses) to be able to open large positions.
We use this to our advantage by letting price run those Liquidity Pools into one of 
the levels like a bearish Orderblock (example on the right).
Notice how aggressively price moves away from that area, that’s the clearest & 
most obvious sign that the “Smart Money” is involved – price has to run the stops 
and quickly move away from that area.
IMPORTANT: when price runs a liquidity pool we want to see a strong expansion to 
the opposite direction right away, if price is not in a rush to leave the liquidity 
pool that’s the first sign that price is NOT ready to go. Informed money will hold 
the price there till there’s enough liquidity swept to take off.

before expanding higher.

## VISUAL MARKERS ON CHART

### Highlighted Zones:
- **Pink/Purple shaded rectangle** (top right area) - marks buyside liquidity zone
- **Blue shaded rectangle** (middle left area) - marks sellside liquidity zone
- **Pink/Purple shaded rectangle** (middle right area) - marks another buyside liquidity zone
- **Pink/Purple shaded rectangle** (right side) - marks another buyside liquidity zone

### Directional Indicators:
- **Black downward arrows** (▼) - positioned above pink zones indicating expected downward movement after liquidity run
- **Black upward arrows** (▲) - positioned below blue zone indicating expected upward movement after liquidity run

---

## CHART STRUCTURE
- Candlestick chart showing price action
- Green/teal candles (bullish)
- Black/red candles (bearish)
- Horizontal reference line across upper portion of chart
- Time axis visible at bottom (showing times: 14, 12:00, 15, 09:00, 17, 18, 12:00, 19, 12:00, 20, 12:00, 21, 12:00, 22, 09:00, 24, 25)

LIQUIDITY MATRIX
To find price exits firstly we must understand the Liquidity Matrix (define the price 
range before the setup forms).
What’s the dealing range high & the dealing range low? – this is how we define a 
PREMIUM Side of the range and the DISCOUNT side of the range.
If the Market is in the Premium – we expect a Sell Program to occur, we want to 
find the counter levels, opposing Premium/Discount Array’s (PDA’s) to cover our 
position, and vice versa when the market is in the Discount – we expect a Buy 
Program to occur, we want to find counter levels, opposing PDA’s to cover our 
position.
Main levels we use as exits: Liquidity, FVG, Equilibrium of the range, BISI/SIBI 
midpoint (CE), opposing breakers, orderblocks.

Internal Liquidity & External Liquidity
In simple terms – everything that’s happening inside the current dealing range 
is “Internal Liquidity”, and everything that’s happening outside the current 
dealing range is “External Liquidity”.
Imagine this – you have a dealing range, you bought in the Discount area, price 
starts expanding higher, reaches Premium side of the range, you take partials 
when price trades into a Premium FVG, and then you see price completely 
breakout above the main (highest) premium level – that’s where price enters 
the External Liquidity area (example on the right).

# INTERNAL LIQUIDITY - Trading Notes Screenshot

## Chart Analysis

### Top Chart (Price Action Overview)
- Shows a complete market cycle: uptrend → downtrend → consolidation → uptrend → distribution
- Clear trending phases with consolidation periods
- Recent price action shows distribution/topping pattern

### Bottom Chart (Detailed Analysis with Annotations)

**Key Levels Marked:**
- **Dealing Range High** (top horizontal line)
- **MT** (marked at upper right)
- **OB** (marked at upper right, just below MT)
- **Dealing Range Low** (bottom horizontal line)

**Annotations and Labels:**

1. **"Dealing Range High"** (top left area)

2. **"High - Lower high close to it makes it a low resistance high."** (left side, during downtrend phase)

3. **"*Clean* low resistance highs = Asia Session High BS Liquidity"** (middle section, with cursor icon 🖱️)

4. **FVG** with cursor icon 🖱️ (marked in middle-right area)

5. **BSLQ** (marked during uptrend phase, left-center)

6. **BMS** (marked near the low, right side)

7. **"Dealing Range Low"** (bottom right area)

**Price Action Features:**
- Multiple swing highs and lows clearly visible
- Consolidation zones highlighted with gray rectangular boxes
- Clean candlestick patterns showing internal liquidity concepts
- Asia session highs identified as liquidity points
- Fair Value Gaps (FVG) marked
- Buy Side Liquidity (BSLQ) and Sell Side concepts illustrated

**Concept Focus:**
The chart demonstrates **INTERNAL LIQUIDITY** - focusing on liquidity within the dealing range, including:
- Low resistance highs
- Asia session highs as BS (Buy Side) liquidity
- Fair Value Gaps
- Clean price action setups within established ranges
